ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

Jurong East Sports complex


    1. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for National Development whether there is any plan for building a sports complex in Jurong East.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, on behalf of my Minister.

    The Housing Board will be building a sports complex at Jurong East. The complex will be at the junction of Boon Lay Way and Jurong Town Hall Road, next to the Chinese Garden.

    This sports complex will have an outdoor stadium, an indoor stadium and swimming pools.

    Building contracts for the complex will be tendered out by the end of this year. The complex is expected to be completed by the end of 1990.

"CLEAN PUBLIC TOILET" CAMPAIGN


    2. Mr Chew Heng Ching asked the Minister for the Environment whether the "Clean Public Toilet" campaign launched in January 1988 has been effective and what follow-up actions are being taken to ensure our public toilets are kept clean.

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, from the

Column: 873

preliminary results of a post-campaign survey being conducted at present, it is observed that public toilets are much cleaner. There is greater acceptance amongst building managements and cleaning contractors of their responsibility to keep public toilets clean and in good working condition. The public is also more conscious now of the need to keep public toilets clean.

    A new Code of Practice on Sanitary Facilities and Fittings for Public Toilets has been drawn up and introduced to all architects, engineers, plumbers and developers. It stresses the use of heavy duty quality fittings and materials for public toilets. New toilets and existing ones undergoing renovation are required to comply with the new Code of Practice. Managers of buildings with public toilets will be made to pay closer attention to the daily maintenance and cleaning of their toilets. Members of the public, on the other hand, should cooperate and show more care and concern for the cleanliness of public toilets.

    Dirty public toilets are certainly not in keeping with our country's "clean and green" image. We hope that with the cooperation of all concerned, there will come a day when we will no longer need to run a "Clean Public Toilets" campaign.

     Mr Chew Heng Ching (Kaki Bukit): Sir, will the Minister pay particular attention to the cleanliness of public toilets in public swimming pools and in recreational areas?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: The answer is yes, Sir.

     Dr Koh Lam Son (Telok Blangah): Sir, the Minister has said that the public toilets are now much cleaner. Can I ask him on what evidence does he base his judgment on?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, since 1983 when we first started the "Clean Public Toilets" campaign, the situation has very much improved. But it is not as good as we would like it to be. I will give you an example. In a survey of nearly 18,000 public toilets conducted in Singapore last year, 13% were still found to be unsatisfactory. That is the reason why we have to keep on holding the campaign.

Column: 874



     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Do these public toilets include toilets in coffeeshops?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: It covers all public toilets - in coffeeshops, HDB estates, swimming complexes, restaurants, shopping complexes - all toilets used by the public.

COMPLAINTS AGAINST TAXI DRIVERS
(Particulars)


    3. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for Communications and Information how many complaints against taxi drivers were received from foreign visitors and local commuters separately by the Registrar of Vehicles in 1985, 1986 and 1987; what were the types of complaints; and what disciplinary actions were taken against the guilty ones.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and Information (Mr Ho Kah Leong) (for the Minister for Communications and Information): Mr Speaker, Sir, on behalf of my Minister.

    The Registrar of Vehicles (ROV) received 931, 684 and 878 complaints against taxi drivers for 1985, 1986 and 1987 respectively. On average, about 12% of complaints originated from foreigners. Of the total number of complaints, about one-third was for overcharging by taxi drivers, one-fifth for misconduct, such as rudeness, and one-tenth each against taxi drivers who refuse to let out their taxis for hire or who take a longer route.

    All these complaints were carefully investigated by the ROV. Where justified, various disciplinary actions were taken against the errant taxi drivers, depending on the severity of their offences. Most of the drivers were counselled, others were issued with written warnings, fined, charged in court, or had their vocational licences suspended or revoked.

STERILIZATION
(Removal of incentives)


    5. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Acting Minister for Health whether there were significant reductions in the requests for both male and female sterilization in 1986 and 1987 and whether he will consider removing some of the incentives for sterilization to discourage it.

     Dr Koh Lam Son: Sir, in asking Question No. 5, I wish to declare my pecuniary interest.

     The Acting Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of male and female sterilizations has been declining over the past 10 years from 10,218 in 1976 to 4,768 cases in 1986. It declined by a further 23% in 1987 to 3,652 cases. In 1986, there were 4,504

Column: 876

female cases as compared to 3,524 cases in 1987. Similarly, the number of male cases declined from 264 cases in 1986 to 128 cases in 1987.

    In line with the New Population Policy, the incentives for sterilizations were revised in March 1987. Women with less than three children wishing to undergo sterilization are currently being counselled by their doctors in both the public and private sectors.

     Dr Koh Lam Son: Sir, can I ask the Minister for the reasons for the decline in the number of cases, and whether there has been a sharper decline in the last one year since the call by the Government to produce more babies? Secondly, whether he would consider removing the incentive of one week's unrecorded leave for civil servants for sterilization.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the reasons for he decline would be, firstly, the continual removal of incentives over the last few years. Secondly, the counselling process that we have started and, thirdly, in line with the New Population Policy, I think women are becoming more aware of the need to not permanently terminate their ability to have children.

    With regard to the unrecorded leave for Government servants, I wish to inform the Member that this has been revised, and that with effect from March 1987 only officers without any GCE 'O' level passes who undergo sterilization after they have had their third child would be available for the seven days unrecorded leave.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Sir, yesterday afternoon before we adjourned, I was responding to the Member for Punggol and also the Member for Nee Soon. Both of them have suggested that my Ministry should reconsider the preferential

Column: 878

margin which is being offered to resettlement shopkeepers. The request is to have a larger preferential margin to help them to secure shops. I would like to give Members some statistics on the success rate of these resettlement shopkeepers in tendering for alternative shop premises.

    Between October 1987 and January 1988, HDB conducted five shop tender exercises in various housing estates. A total of 197 resettlement shopkeepers submitted tenders in these five exercises. Eighteen out of the 197 were successful. Out of the 18 successful resettlement tenderers, 15 of them were successful without having to rely on their preferential margin. Only three of the resettlement shopkeepers had to depend on the preferential margin to secure their shops. This result shows that the success rate of the resettlement shopkeepers, which is one in 11, is slightly better than that of the public tender held for the same period. In the case of the public tender for the period, there were 591 successful tenders out of 6,848 or 1 in 11.6.

    The other significant point, Sir, is that the majority, 15 out of the 18 successful resettlement tenderers, succeeded in their tenders without relying on preferential margin. These results indicate that it is not the preferential margin which determines the outcome of a tender. What is more important and significant is the business acumen of the resettlement shopkeepers.

    Sir, the present preferential margins are considered adequate to enable interested and viable resettlement shopkeepers to enter the current rental market for HDB shops.

    The Member for Nee Soon also asked whether some shops could be set aside exclusively for the resettlement shopkeepers. If Members would recall, the policy changes to the resettlement schemes announced on 28th July 1987 were done so after careful consideration and study. The problem is that HDB simply does not have enough shops to offer to all the resettlement shopkeepers. On 28th July 1987 when the policy changes were announced, there were 2,075 resettlement cases pending. HDB had only 546 shops available. Considering that from now on HDB will be building about 150 shops a

Column: 879

year, it is quite obvious that not all resettlement shopkeepers will be able to get a new shop under the old scheme. On top of this, out of the 546 shops available in July 1987, there were many shops which had seen a succession of business failures. That was why they were still vacant then. If they were good shops in choice locations, they would not have been vacant. They would have been snapped up long before that.

    So reserving these shops for resettlement shopkeepers will not do them any good in the long term. With the new policy, which is, no alternative premises but instead a cash compensation, these shopkeepers are free to tender for shops which in their own judgement are most suitable for their business.

    I hope both the Members for Punggol and Nee Soon will understand why the new resettlement scheme is here to stay.

    Finally, I would like to respond to the comments made by the Member for Chua Chu Kang who asked the Government to be quick in paying compensation to resettled shopkeepers and farmers. Sir, in working out the amount of compensation due to people affected by resettlement, the Resettlement Department has to conduct a physical examination of all the qualifying items in every case. During the assessment exercise, every item of improvement is counted, measured and assessed according to approved compensation rates and guidelines under the resettlement policy. Counter-checking and verifying has to be done separately by HDB's auditors before payment can be released. This procedure is time-consuming but necessary to ensure accuracy and a fair compensation. It takes normally three months from the time of field assessment to payment of a compensation. A longer time of four to five months may be needed to process compensation for extensive farming cases. In some cases, there may be complications arising from disputes about the way the assessment was conducted or the items which were included or excluded. Whenever such disputes arise, invariably the processing time is lengthened.

Column: 880



    The Resettlement Department carries out assessments of its own procedures from time to time with the objective of trying to expedite payments to all resettlement cases. In Chua Chu Kang Constituency, a large number of resettlement cases are farmers and squatters who have carried out extensive improvements on their land. It takes more time to process such cases.

    The Member for Chua Chu Kang also raised the issue of resettlement folks who were "deemed not to be interested" in resettlement flats after they have failed to select a flat on three occasions. The truth of the matter, Sir, is that the majority of resettlement cases successfully picked their flats within the three offers made to them. Between January and February 1988, 2,400 cases were handled by the Resettlement Department. Only 37 cases failed to select flats after the third offer. In other words, only 1.5% of all resettlement cases during that two-month period were affected. Even then the Resettlement Department does not disregard the needs of these resettlement folks. In fact, even after the third offer is rejected, a resettlement person will be given a new priority number. HDB will continue to make offers of flats to him. He will still retain some priority and does not have to compete with public applicants for flats. In other words, he still qualifies for the flats that are set aside for resettlement cases. And in some localities, as my Minister has told Members yesterday, up to 50% of flats in any locality can be set aside for resettlement cases.

    Once a resettlement case has picked a flat, the Department will also expedite the assessment of compensation due to him, if this has not been completed as yet. So the Department is making every effort to expedite all payments of compensation. However, in view of the Member's appeal, I will ask the Resettlement Department to conduct a another review of its procedures to see if further improvements can be made to shorten the processing time.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Sir, I would just like to make a very brief reply to the Member for Punggol on the point he raised about the need to integrate our road networks and

Column: 881

also to ensure that the New Towns are inter-connected.

    The planning of the road network has always been considered on the basis of linking all the major traffic generators such as residential towns, industrial areas and commercial centres. When the major part of the expressway network is completed by the mid-1990s, there will be an efficient inter-town linkage among all the HDB New Towns. In fact, the transportation plan within the HDB New Towns, as planned by HDB, is integrated fully with the PWD's network of expressways and major arterial roads. For example, Hougang New Town is connected to the Central Expressway by Hougang Avenue 2 and to the PIE by Hougang Avenue 3. So there is, in fact, sufficient attention paid to this aspect.

    Sir, as we still have probably about 10-15 minutes on this item, I thought it would be a good opportunity to allow the Member for Potong Pasir to raise the questions which he wanted to raise yesterday.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): I am much obliged to you, Mr Deputy Speaker. There are two questions which I would like the Minister to answer, both in regard to the pricing of HDB flats. The first one is, would the Minister be willing to announce or make public the market value of all the land in the housing estates used by the HDB? Now the Minister has come out quite forthrightly, unlike his predecessor, to say that the pricing of HDB flats, in fact, includes the land cost at market value. This market value is a very volatile concept or a very unsure one because market value can mean really anything, depending on what the HDB would like to peg the market value on. If the HDB could give an indication, then I think the public would know how much their flats really cost. Because successful tenders of construction cost are usually gazetted, so we have information on that. But up to now, the land cost has been a complete mystery. I think the Minister should have this cost of land

Column: 882

value because he put up a table which was distributed yesterday, and this table does not really give any details of how the price of each individual flat is arrived at.

    The other question is the unit cost per flat. The Opposition has been at this since, I think, 1984 but we were unsuccessful every year. All kinds of excuses were given. If the Minister would remember, the former Minister said that it was difficult to give the unit cost because it varies from area to area. To make it easy, perhaps we confine ourselves to each particular New Town. I am sure he has figures of each unit cost.

    Until the Minister can enlighten us on that, I think the two points which the HDB has always been canvassing cannot really be cleared up from the air. No. 1 - HDB has been subsidizing the flats; and No. 2 - the HDB has not been making a profit. Of course, we in the SDP have said to the contrary. We do not believe that the flats are subsidized in the sense that the HDB has taken money, out of pocket, to top up what they have lost in regard to cost per flat. And also we say that the HDB does make profits in the sale of their flats.

    As regards land, I think everybody knows that when land is acquired compulsorily, normally the compensation is based, in the past, on 1973 values. But after the new law was passed, land value is taken at the price in January 1986 for those lands that are acquired after November 1986. Somebody asked the Minister why the price of land was taken at January 1986, and he was quite forthright: "because prices of land at that time were at its lowest point." We can see that the land acquired by the Government is almost for a song. We know that land in outlying areas, was acquired and compensation was paid at something like 60> per sq ft. And not long ago I even read of rubber land at Mandai being acquised and the Government compensated the landowners something like 15> per sq ft. So it would be interesting to see what is the market value of the various estates which the HDB has taken. I think this is an important point because I think the public would go along with the Government to allow their land to be compulsorily acquired at a very low value, and not only at a very low value but,

Column: 883

in fact, a lot of hardship has been endured by those people who have been evicted from their land forcibly against their will. I think many MPs have spoken about resettlement and, in fact, the story of the human side of the resettlement has not really been fully told.

    As I said, the public would go along with the Government and allow their land to be compulsorily acquired if they know that the land acquired is to be used for public purposes, for the national good. But if the market value fixed by the Government is so high and it can be deemed by the public that, in fact, the Government is using the Land Acquisition Act to make a profit on their land, then I am afraid it would be very difficult in future for the Government to acquire land. There will be more resistance to it.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir. I just wish to make a clarification on the Hon. Minister's statement yesterday. Could I ask him why he made no mention of my GPC's recommendations vis-a-vis HDB's new role in public housing and land use, particularly concerning lands at Marina South and East Coast? Is it because we are on the same wave length? As can be seen from his statement, the GPC made those recommendations and this was not acknowledged.

    Government policy on HDB public housing will now be shifted to full home ownership which would mean affordability of a 3-room flat. Here, we cannot disagree with him. However, we would like to ask him whether this will mean that HDB's 4-room, 5-room, Executive apartments and maisonettes will now be priced higher. As I said, we agree with the full home ownership but not 100% ownership which, we think, is not realistic.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Member for Potong Pasir wants to know whether the HDB will make public the value of individual lots. Of course, the HDB does have details of the value of individual lots. But I must take very strong

Column: 884

objection and, I think, the profession of valuers in Singapore will take very strong objection to his suggestion that the value of land is completely arbitrary. It is not arbitrary. It is not up to the HDB to peg it to any level that it wants. As I mentioned yesterday, I would suggest that the Member for Potong Pasir should try and get hold of a copy of the text, and if he cannot, I will let him have a copy of the text of what I said yesterday: the value of the land that the HDB purchases is fixed by the Chief Valuer.

    There are very specific criteria and approach that valuers use in order to arrive at the value of a piece of land. Land is sold and bought all over Singapore all the time, not just private land but also Government land. And using the sale prices of land between willing buyer and willing seller, valuers are able to make the kind of adjustments necessary to arrive at the value of land in other areas or adjacent areas. So it is not arbitrary. In fact, valuers have claimed that though they exercise judgment, their approach is a rather scientific and rigorous one.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Subjective.

     Mr Dhanabalan: It is not. As I said, they have to exercise judgment but it is not just completely arbitrary. I have already explained yesterday why we had to use market value of land. But I did make it very clear that HDB prices do not cover the market value of land, which is why 98% of the flats completed have a subsidy element. And I made it very clear what we mean by subsidy.

    I would urge the Member to get his thinking right. It is not a question of whether you spend money out of pocket. The point I made was that as long as HDB sells its flats at a price lower than what the purchaser has to pay in the market, there is a subsidy. And this has been demonstrated again and again by HDB purchasers being able to sell on the market at a price higher than what they paid the HDB. That is the only rational, logical definition of subsidy.

    I made this point once before. If the Member were to give his son a house which he had bought 10 years ago, either free or even at cost, would he not think that he has done his son a favour?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: That is different.

     Mr Dhanabalan: It is not different. The point I am making is that you would be giving a benefit to somebody which he would not get if he were to go into the market to get that particular service or that particular asset.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: That is father and son relationship.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Or it can be to anybody. So there is no purpose in trying to pursue this point, what is the cost? I have already said that I have asked the HDB to let us know what the historical values are, just for us to note. But HDB has used the market value as a guide to price its flats. And it is very obvious and quite conclusive from the evidence I gave yesterday that 98% of the flats are priced below what they are worth on the market. And people know.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: We do not know.

     Mr Dhanabalan: If the HDB purchaser thinks that he is paying the HDB more than what he can pay on the market, he would not buy from the HDB. HDB is not the only developer in the market. It is very simple. There are private developers. They build apartments. Some of them look very much like HDB apartments. People are free to buy those apartments.

     Mr Dhanabalan: So the question of whether HDB makes a profit does not arise. As I said, at the end of every year, HDB totes up what it costs to build its flats, which means construction cost, development and infrastructural costs, the land

price that it pays the Government. It totes what it gets by way of its sales receipts, and there is a very big deficit which is shown in the budget, and it runs into billions of dollars. If the Member for Potong Pasir does not want to understand, then of course there is no way I can make him understand.
